By the side of the Camberwell road</br>The beauteous Blowzinda was laid,</br>With tears were her eyes overflowed,</br>And most piteously sigh'd the poor maid.
No powder was there in her hair,</br>No spirit was there in her eye,</br>She was full, — aye, quite brim-full of care,</br>And alas!  could do nothing but sigh!
Young Sixteen-String passing hard by,</br>And seeing her thus in her dumps,</br>Tho' he'd got on his cordovan boots,</br>Ran as if he had been in his pumps.
Ah!  tell me, delight of my eyes,</br>The shepherd immediately said,</br>From whence do thy sorrows arise?</br>Let me be thy confidante made?
Haste, haste, to the Dog and Duck come,</br>Ah!  hook thy white hand on my arm;</br>A bowl of new milk and old rum,</br>Will act on thy heart like a charm.
The FLASHES already are there,</br>The lights makes a glittering show,</br>Then away with thy sighs — not a tear—</br>To the winds cast thy care and thy woe.
BLOWZINDA.</br>Ah!  cease, cease, cease thy fond lay—</br>There, there is the cause of my grief,</br>The licence is taken away,</br>And my sorrow admits no relief!
This evening — I spake with a sigh,</br>At the Horse Guards I took me a hack,</br>To the Dog and Duck, fellow!  says I,</br>And away we whirl'd off with a smack.
But to find, when I came to the place,</br>That the Gentleman's licence was stopt,</br>The big tear ran down from my face,</br>And I thought that I there should have dropt.
SIXTEEN-STRING.</br>Stop his licence!  it never can be!</br>If they have — let their Worships take care;</br>I'll rob them all round, d'ye see—</br>But come, my girl, never despair.
I know of another good house,</br>And to that we will now hike away;</br>This night we will have a carouze,</br>And on reckoning the Quorum shall pay.</br>
